instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2914: What is 820-2914? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.U4900: What is U4900? This is the System Management Controller(SMC) in older(pre-2013) macbooks.
definitions.820-2565: What is 820-2565? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.R7005: What is R7005? resistor between charger and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, if CHGR_DCIN is low then this resistor is probably blown. When PPBUS_G3H is low or missing this is something to check if your model has CHGR_DCIN along R7005. .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dim green light (powered on once)
threads.message:
I got this 17" 2011 MBP sent from another repair shop with this note.
"Magsafe adapter fades to black after a few seconds and the device won't power on. Tried SMC bypass with no luck. Replaced dc board but still the same symptoms"

When I initially plugged in my charger the fans started spinning and the magsafe light was bright green. After a second or two the fans stopped spinning then they spun again and the machine chimed and booted and I was able to login and play with a few things like internet and camera. The battery was charging then all of a sudden it stopped charging and the magsafe light went dim and soon after it shut down and I haven't been able to get it back on.

I am using a genuine Apple 85w charger.

I've tried plugging in 2 other <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2565</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> magsafe boards(not sure if there compatible) and still the light is dim green.
When I take a look at the logic board I can see discolored probe points as if there was liquid damage that got cleaned up. Some by the SMC(<CHIP>U4900</CHIP>)

<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.45v'
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - fluctuates quickly between 2.9v to 3.4v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 0.48v (With battery and charger plugged in 10.4v)
Pins1/2 of <CHIP>U6901</CHIP>(<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL>) - 0v
Pin 5 <CHIP>U6900</CHIP> (Adapter Sense) - 0v

Pins 19/20 of <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> (VDD Pins) - 2.5v (<RESISTOR>R7001</RESISTOR> measured proper resistance)
Resistance Pins 17/18 - 3.6ohms - Pins 27/28 - 21ohms

Shouldn't that be 5.1v and where is it created? I believe in the newer schematics that is created by the 3v42 circuit

threads.message:
Pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> fluctuates quickly from 15.97 to 16.68v
Resistance of <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> is 13kohms. I should replace that right?

Resistance to ground on Pin 2 of <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is showing around 6 Mega ohms

[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dim green light (powered on once)
threads.message:
Replaced it now the machine is back working. Thanks a lot.

This topic can be marked solved.
